title: Mademoiselle Cocyte

thumbnail.alt_text: A work made of red and black chalk, with stumping, on ivory wove paper.

medium_display: Red and black chalk, with stumping, on ivory wove paper
credit_line: Gift of Dorothy Braude Edinburg to the Harry B. and Bessie K. Braude Memorial Collection
publication_history:
Maurice Joyant, Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec, dessins, estampes, affiches (Paris: H. Floury, 1927), vol. 1, pp. 238; vol. 2, pp. 165, 241 (ill.).

Maurice Joyant, Dessins de maitres français: Toulouse-Lautrec, vol. 9 (Paris: Helleu et Sergent, 1930), no. 71 (ill.).

Gerstle Mack, Toulouse-Lautrec (New York: Knopf, 1938), p. 214.

M. G. Dortu, Toulouse-Lautrec et son oeuvre vol. 6 (New York: Collectors Editions, 1971), no. D 4.641, pp. 900–01 (ill.).

Galeries Nationales du Grand Palais, Toulouse-Lautrec (Paris: Réunion des musées nationaux, 1992), p. 506, fig. a.

Suzanne Folds McCullagh (ed.), Drawings in Dialogue: Old Master Through Modern, The Harry B. and Bessie K. Braude Memorial Collection, exh. cat. (Chicago: The Art Institute of Chicago, 2006), p. 129, cat. 90 (ill.).
exhibition_history:
Paris, Galerie Manzi Joyant, "Toulouse-Lautrec Retrospective," June15–July 11, 1914, cat. 183, as Figurante de Messaline.

Paris, Musée des arts décoratifs, "Toulouse-Lautrec Trentenaire," Apr. 9–May 17, 1931, cat. 285.

Paris, Galerie Bernheim-Jeune, "Cent Ans de théâtre, music hall et cirque," 1936, cat. 98.

Paris, Galerie Knoedler, "Toulouse-Lautrec: Paintings and Drawings," Jan. 19–Feb. 2, 1938, cat. 49.

Paris, Galerie de Quatre Chemins, "Toulouse-Lautrec," 1938, cat. 13.

Paris, Musée de l’Orangerie, "Toulouse-Lautrec: Exposition en l’honneur du cinquantième anniversaire de sa mort," 1951, cat. 119.

Basel, Galerie Beyeler, "La Femme: Peintures et sculptures," May–June 1960, cat. 1a.

Art Institute of Chicago, "Drawings in Dialogue: Old Master Through Modern, The Harry B. and Bessie K. Braude Memorial Collection," June 3–July 30, 2006, p. 129, cat. 90 (ill.).
provenance_text: The artist’s estate [stamp (Lugt 1338), recto, lower left, in orange].  Maurice Joyant (1864–1930), Paris; probably by descent to Mme. Dortu, by 1931.  Private collector, Paris; sold, Christie’s, London, Dec. 4, 1990, lot 117, to Dorothy Braude Edinburg, Brookline, MA; given to the Art Institute of Chicago, 2013.
